title: Wu responds to Kraft’s decision to drop out of mayoral race
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Mayor Michelle Wu responded to Josh Kraft's withdrawal from the mayoral race, thanking him for his commitment to the city.
Kraft, previously trailing Wu with 23.07% of votes, plans to donate $3 million to fight drug addiction and homelessness.
If Kraft removes his name, Domingos DaRosa, who received 2,409 votes, may not qualify to replace him on the November ballot.

title: Travis Barker and Kourtney Kardashian toured Salem
author: Megan Johnson
bullets: Travis Barker and Kourtney Kardashian toured Salem, Massachusetts, between Blink-182 concerts in New Hampshire and New York.
The couple participated in a Witch City Walking Tour, exploring Salem's historic sites with their son, Rocky.
Barker and Kardashian were seen dining at Gulu-Gulu Cafe in Salem, maintaining a low profile during the visit.

title: Law enforcement source identifies the Charlie Kirk shooting suspect in custody
author: The Associated Press
bullets: A suspect, Tyler Robinson, 22, was arrested for the shooting of Charlie Kirk at Utah Valley University.
President Donald Trump confirmed the arrest, noting a minister's involvement in identifying Robinson to authorities.
The FBI and state officials had released images seeking public help before the suspect's arrest.

title: Your new Cape house could be a 245-square-foot cottage in Eastham for $259,000
author: Megan Johnson
bullets: 245-square-foot cottage in Eastham listed for $259,000, featuring one bedroom and one bathroom.
Built in 1940, the cottage is part of a 10-unit colony, renovated in 2000 by Chris Nagle.
Residents enjoy proximity to the National Seashore, with a $135 quarterly HOA fee covering amenities.

title: A Newburyport teen’s body was unidentified for 33 years. Now, his aunt and a cold-case aficionado want to bring him home.
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Anthony Angelli Rea was identified 33 years after his remains were found in Newburyport using genome sequencing.
His aunt, Carolann Angelli, discovered the match through a DNA test and seeks to repatriate his remains.
Cold-case enthusiast Maya Ambrose helped raise funds for Rea's burial with his family through a GoFundMe.

title: Did you follow the local news this week? Take our Greater Boston news quiz.
author: Peter Chianca
bullets: Boston.com released a news quiz featuring questions about Hasbro and local figures like Matt Damon and Ben Affleck.
Aroldis Chapman and Arthur T. Demoulas are included in the topics covered by this week's Greater Boston news quiz.
Boston.com's news quiz aims to keep readers informed and tests their knowledge of recent local events.

title: Amid opt-out rumors, Sam Kennedy says Alex Bregman ‘wants to be here’ with Red Sox
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Red Sox's Alex Bregman can opt out of his contract after the 2025 season to potentially seek a long-term deal.
ESPN's Jeff Passan reports Bregman plans to opt out unless injured, aiming for a deal over five years at $35 million annually.
Red Sox President Sam Kennedy expressed surprise at the opt-out rumors, affirming both parties want Bregman to remain in Boston.

title: Bill Belichick says in new book that Tom Brady made ‘right decision’ to leave Patriots in 2020
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Bill Belichick says Tom Brady made the right decision leaving the Patriots in 2020 due to a weak team lineup.
Belichick acknowledges the Patriots faced financial constraints and a need to rebuild after the 2019 season.
Tom Brady's departure led to continued success with the Buccaneers, winning a Super Bowl and achieving high personal stats.

title: West Boylston town administrator fired after Trump flag dispute sues town
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Ex-West Boylston administrator James Ryan sues town for $1.3 million, claiming wrongful termination over a Trump flag dispute.
Ryan alleges he was fired after enforcing town by-laws on political signage against Police Chief Dennis Minnich's actions.
Police Chief Minnich opposed Ryan's flag removal request, leading to a conflict and Ryan's eventual firing by Select Board.

title: 18-year-old injured in R.I. after lighting himself on fire for TikTok challenge
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: An 18-year-old was severely burned in North Smithfield, R.I. attempting a TikTok challenge on September 6, 2025.
The challenge involved lighting oneself on fire with gasoline and jumping off a railway trestle into a reservoir.
The teen was hospitalized with second- and third-degree burns; his 16-year-old companion was not injured.
